channel.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
channel.description:
ok a classmate is planning on buying a laptop for $4000 :eek:. idk what kind it is or what hes going to be using it for. about the only thing i can think of would be alienware and maybe a couple of others that would cost that much. if i was him i wouldnt spend that much on a laptop, the rest of my classmate agree. i believe that this laptop would have plenty of power for what ever he needs: [url=http://www.gateway.com/systems/product/529668662.php]http://www.gateway.com/systems/product/529668662.php[/url] . so i decided to browse the net and try to compile a list of parts to make a computer on a $4000 budget. i personally have never bought(no $$$:() and built my own pc yet. so if what i picked isnt compatible with each other sorry, but as far as i know they should be compatible. heres my list(excluding tax, shipping, and accessories):
MOBO: GIGABYTE GA-X58A-UD5 - $290 http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813128422 CPU: Intel i7-980x - $1000 http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819115223 Memory: ddr3 2200 * 3 - $480 http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820231322 Storage: SSD: 32GB - $93 // holds the programs and anything else that needs fast reads http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820211419 HDD: 1TB - $90 // for everything else http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16822136533 ODD: DVD/cd burner - $30 //i dont use ODDs very much so i usually forget about them but if the game you play needs a disc then i guess you need one http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16827140042 Computer case: ATX Full tower - $180 http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811119225 Cooling system: ALC - $72 // hoping thing is enough to keep my $1000 cpu from frying http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16835227006 Gfx cards: GTX 580 * 2 - $1040 // why? idk just for fun http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814130587 PSU: 1000w - $200 // im thinking it would probably need a bigger one though http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817610004 Total coming out to $3,477 thats $523 less than he is going to spend and i highly doubt he is going to get that kinda performance out of a laptop.
i havent browsed around looking for cheaper prices on these products, which i would do if i was buying this for myself. so leave your list of part you would buy if you were building you pc on a $4000 budget. ill probably learn something. thx.

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

I think it boils down to the fact of what would you rather have? Durex or Asda Price?

Read full topic

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“abatssk8ter, post:13, topic:371072”][quote author=jmood128 link=topic=467157.msg3416962#msg3416962 date=1291166972]

I’d get a decent mac.

Waste of money like Alien ware.
[/quote]Not at all. Performance is superior.[/quote]

Not at all. I would rather pay less and have a server that performs just as good and even better then having to pay an arm and a leg for something…

Read full topic

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“jmood128, post:11, topic:371072”][quote author=abatssk8ter link=topic=467157.msg3416943#msg3416943 date=1291166011]
I’d get a decent mac.
[/quote]

Waste of money like Alien ware.[/quote] dont get me wrong i like macs but i agree with jmood. you can build your own pc and install mac os x on it, its not to hard but you have to have an intel cpu. you barely may get more performance if you fully upgrade a mac pro but that would be in the $10000 range.

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @Spades Spades
item.description:
@Spades wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”]Alienware is shit.

It’s only a shitty Dell with a cool outer casing.[/quote]

AlienWare was good before Dell came in and took everything over, if you can get an AlienWare built before Dell it is most likely better then anything they are building now.

Read full topic
item.source: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Mendorphins, post:4, topic:371072”][quote]
HDD:
1TB - $90 // for everything else
[/quote]

That’s cheap! My mate bought a 160GB HDD for £65. $90 is £65? Or is the Dollar double the Pound.[/quote]

http://www.google.co.uk/products/catalog?q=1tb+hdd&um=1&ie=UTF-8&cid=1366483808779858026&ei=PS_0TLePGqKShAf4_eSyDA&sa=X&oi=product_catalog_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q8wIwAA#

Not that cheap really, that one there converts to just under $60.

[quote=“xryz, post:5, topic:371072”][quote author=I Vain I link=topic=467157.msg3415948#msg3415948 date=1291070417]
Alienware is shit.

It’s only a shitty Dell with a cool outer casing.
[/quote]
that would be my feelings towards alienware as well.

[quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=467157.msg3415956#msg3415956 date=1291070664]

OT: better off choosing a triple channel RAM kit considering that’s what the motherboard supports.
[/quote] so something like 2 of these would be better: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820231374?[/quote]
Yeah that’s better, only that RAM doesn’t have the max speed the motherboard can hold, nevertheless, it could always be overclocked.

Read full topic
item.source: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”][quote author=Mendorphins link=topic=467157.msg3415969#msg3415969 date=1291071213]

HDD:
1TB - $90 // for everything else

That’s cheap! My mate bought a 160GB HDD for £65. $90 is £65? Or is the Dollar double the Pound.
[/quote]
£65 is roughly $102.00 USD.[/quote]

1TB HDD for $90 is definitely cheap then.

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=467157.msg3415956#msg3415956 date=1291070664]

Alienware is shit.

It’s only a shitty Dell with a cool outer casing.

I disagree, I play Black Ops and GTA IV on my Dell laptop, I’ve never had any problems.

OT: better off choosing a triple channel RAM kit considering that’s what the motherboard supports.
[/quote]Not saying Dell is bad, as I use both Dell and Compaq, I was only stating that Alienware sucks as it’s a normal Dell with a ‘cool’ case.

Thus, spending 2x cash for a plastic case for a computer.[/quote]

Well, Dell owns Alienware so they’re bound to be somewhat similar, but yeah, I agree, an awful lot of the money probably goes to the pretty lighting and casing, but if you’re spending that much money anyway, wouldn’t you want it to stand out?
And of course, they do put different hardware in each model…

Read full topic
item.source: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?

It’s only a shitty Dell with a cool outer casing.[/quote]

I disagree, I play Black Ops and GTA IV on my Dell laptop, I’ve never had any problems.

OT: better off choosing a triple channel RAM kit considering that’s what the motherboard supports.

Read full topic

item.title: How would you build a pc with a $4000 budget?
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

ok a classmate is planning on buying a laptop for $4000 :eek:. idk what kind it is or what hes going to be using it for. about the only thing i can think of would be alienware and maybe a couple of others that would cost that much. if i was him i wouldnt spend that much on a laptop, the rest of my classmate agree. i believe that this laptop would have plenty of power for what ever he needs: http://www.gateway.com/systems/product/529668662.php . so i decided to browse the net and try to compile a list of parts to make a computer on a $4000 budget. i personally have never bought(no $$$:() and built my own pc yet. so if what i picked isnt compatible with each other sorry, but as far as i know they should be compatible. heres my list(excluding tax, shipping, and accessories):

MOBO: GIGABYTE GA-X58A-UD5 - $290 http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813128422

CPU:
Intel i7-980x - $1000

newegg.com

Storage:
SSD:
32GB - $93 // holds the programs and anything else that needs fast reads

HDD:
1TB - $90 // for everything else
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16822136533
ODD:
DVD/cd burner - $30 //i dont use ODDs very much so i usually forget about them but if the game you play needs a disc then i guess you need one
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16827140042

1000w - $200 // im thinking it would probably need a bigger one though

Total coming out to $3,477

thats $523 less than he is going to spend and i highly doubt he is going to get that kinda performance out of a laptop.


i havent browsed around looking for cheaper prices on these products, which i would do if i was buying this for myself. so leave your list of part you would buy if you were building you pc on a $4000 budget. ill probably learn something. thx.
